title: Bulk UUID enumeration via invite codes
vulnerability_information:
It is possible to enumerate UUID via invite code. During signup if we enter invite code then ```create``` request's response contains ```inviter_uuid``` . As invite codes are public  so attacker can easily enumerate  bulk UUID . 

Here is sample request :-

```
POST /signup/clients/create HTTP/1.1
X-Uber-RedirectCount: 0
X-Uber-DCURL: https://cn-geo1.uber.com/
User-Agent: client/android/3.104.5
X-Uber-Origin: android-client
X-Uber-Device-Location-Latitude: 26.894606
X-Uber-Device-Location-Longitude: 75.7562847
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
Host: cn-geo1.uber.com
Connection: Keep-Alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip
Content-Length: 1809

{
	"deviceData": {
		"androidId": "b3f675hc5e15531",
		"version": "3.104.5",
		"batteryStatus": "discharging",
		"carrier": "",
		"carrierMcc": "404",
		"carrierMnc": "59",
		"simSerial": "9915921251419234722",
		"cpuAbi": "armeabi, armeabi-v7a",
		"phoneNumber": "",
		"deviceIds": {
			"authId": "k361075b11131493a6061925",
			"permId": "k973d2529d728186b9063522cb48d74b",
			"deviceImei": "851639131157164"
		},
		"md5": "184ec02b309a23dedfc90f6bfe0dfab",
		"ipAddress": "192.168.0.171",
		"deviceModel": "HM NOTE 1LTE",
		"deviceOsName": "Android",
		"deviceOsVersion": "4.4.4",
		"imsi": "50459415423472",
		"batteryLevel": 0.81,
		"deviceAltitude": 0.0,
		"deviceLongitude": 75.7562847,
		"deviceLatitude": 26.894606,
		"locationServiceEnabled": true,
		"mockGpsOn": false,
		"emulator": false,
		"rooted": true,
		"course": 0.0,
		"speed": 0.0,
		"unknownSources": false,
		"horizontalAccuracy": 24.0,
		"wifiConnected": true
	},
	"device_ids": {
		"device_imei": "51639131957164",
		"googleAdvertisingId": "anba81e-ecde-419a-a1c4-0eb0f6768887"
	},
	"altitude": 0.0,
	"horizontal_accuracy": 24.0,
	"device_mobile_country_iso2": "in",
	"password": "vijay",
	"version": "3.104.5",
	"course": 0.0,
	"device_os": "4.4.4",
	"signup_form": "android",
	"first_name": "Test",
	"device_model": "HM NOTE 1LTE",
	"device_mobile_digits": "",
	"signup_session_id": "f8eb7f0-5ab5-433b-aa97-88d434fe2224",
	"longitude": 75.7562847,
	"app": "client",
	"promotion_code": "uber48",
	"mobile_country_iso2": "IN",
	"device_serial_number": "9CAE0F2D091",
	"speed": 0.0,
	"epoch": 1466074494001,
	"device_id": "r9ee4b0668ccbccdbb454c3c7791ee47",
	"email": "testh1vijay5@gmail.com",
	"last_name": "Account",
	"device": "android",
	"token_type": "cash",
	"latitude": 26.894606,
	"language": "en_US",
	"mobile": "97558 47368"
}
```

and response is-


Second last line of response contains ```inviter_uuid``` .
Please note that uber only allow 3 account per device if we choose payment method as cash. But we can bypass it by taking androidId,simSerial,imsi,googleAdvertisingId,signup_session_id  in variable during Attack.
I  tested with 45 requests and all request were successful. 

Thanks

activities.message:
Hi @apara,

Thanks you for your report and for your patience while we look into this. I just wanted to let you know that we are still investigating your issue and you should get a definitive response soon.

Thanks again for your understanding,
-mike

i think it can be easily fixed by removing `inviter_uuid` from response .

activities.message: Hey @apara, thanks for the ping. You are correct, this one seems to be resolved. I'm updating it as such, sorry for the delay. As I'm sure you know we have meetings every few weeks to discuss `Resolved` reports and we will follow up after the next one to determine if this submission was eligible under our bug bounty program. Thank you!
activities.markdown_message: Hey @apara, thanks for the ping. You are correct, this one seems to be resolved. I'm updating it as such, sorry for the delay. As I'm sure you know we have meetings every few weeks to discuss Resolved reports and we will follow up after the next one to determine if this submission was eligible under our bug bounty program. Thank you!

additional_data.new_title: Bulk UUID enumeration via invite codes

activities.message:
Awesome ! Thanks for update . :)
if i read your scope correctly "Bulk UUID enumeration" is listed as Great and unique issue at [Uber Treasure Map](https://eng.uber.com/bug-bounty) and also at [Uber Hackerone page](https://hackerone.com/uber). Anyway i will wait for your decision.

Thanks
activities.markdown_message:
Awesome ! Thanks for update . :)
if i read your scope correctly "Bulk UUID enumeration" is listed as Great and unique issue at Uber Treasure Map and also at Uber Hackerone page. Anyway i will wait for your decision.

Thanks

activities.message: Thanks for the report, @apara! We encourage you to continue participating in Uber's bug bounty program in the future.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the report, @apara! We encourage you to continue participating in Uber's bug bounty program in the future.

activities.message:
Hi , Thanks for bounty.
But bulk uuid enumeration issue is listed as medium issue($3k) at hackerone page. I was hoping 3k for this report because this report meet all your condition like enumeration of uuid of any arbitrary user , no rate limiting allow to enumerate uuid in bulk etc. Also this report have more impact than enumeration of uuid by email/phone because an attacker  can  easily manage Vitim's invite code than email or phone number. Can you clarify why this report not qualify for $3k ??
activities.markdown_message:
Hi , Thanks for bounty.
But bulk uuid enumeration issue is listed as medium issue($3k) at hackerone page. I was hoping 3k for this report because this report meet all your condition like enumeration of uuid of any arbitrary user , no rate limiting allow to enumerate uuid in bulk etc. Also this report have more impact than enumeration of uuid by email/phone because an attacker can easily manage Vitim's invite code than email or phone number. Can you clarify why this report not qualify for $3k ??

activities.message:
Hey @lyoung-uber @uber , I am waiting for your response on my last comment. And please disclose this report publicly.

Thanks
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @lyoung-uber @uber , I am waiting for your response on my last comment. And please disclose this report publicly.

Thanks

activities.message:
Hey @apara, sorry for the delayed response. 

> Can you clarify why this report not qualify for $3k ??

Absolutely, the reason this didn't fully qualify for the $3k mentioned on our HackerOne page is because there were mitigating factors in the enumeration. In order to abuse this endpoint you would need a list of valid invite codes. Unlike phone number or email address based enumeration which could be obtained from other external sources invite codes are specific to Uber and would have to be mass enumerated through another bug. Hopefully that helps.

If you'd still like to publicly disclose let me know and I'll approve it from our end.
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @apara, sorry for the delayed response.

Can you clarify why this report not qualify for $3k ??

Absolutely, the reason this didn't fully qualify for the $3k mentioned on our HackerOne page is because there were mitigating factors in the enumeration. In order to abuse this endpoint you would need a list of valid invite codes. Unlike phone number or email address based enumeration which could be obtained from other external sources invite codes are specific to Uber and would have to be mass enumerated through another bug. Hopefully that helps.

If you'd still like to publicly disclose let me know and I'll approve it from our end.

activities.message:
Hey @lyoung-uber ,
I don't think there are mitigating factors in the enumeration.

>In order to abuse this endpoint you would need a list of valid invite codes.

I can list many way to enumerate invite codes in bulk. 
Eg.
1. I already mention in my report that rate limiting is missing on `create` request so an attacker can get all valid invite code by brute force attack. If invite code is invalid then it will throw `invalid invite code` in response and if invite code is valid then it will create new account and will give `inviter_uuid` in the response .( i already shown this in my video poc) .
Also all customized invite codes begin with "uber" so invite codes are easily bruteforcable .
2. Invite codes are public and shared by users on internet , you can check by searching keywords "uber free ride invite code" , "get.uber.com/invite/" etc. in google and you will get hundreds of link containing invite code.

I am sure this report is not evaluated properly. Hope you will again look into this.

Thanks

activities.message: Hey @apara, I've reviewed both your and @lyoung-uber's comments about the severity of this issue and I'm sorry that you are unhappy with the bounty that we offered. Sometimes similar seeming issues end up with differing bounties because of the specific details of each one. The payouts are determined based off an estimate of the impact that a given vulnerability poses and we make every effort to be consistent and fair. We feel we did so with regard to this ticket. We cannot revisit paid bounty amounts except under extraordinary circumstances. We hope you understand and continue to participate in our bug bounty program.
